Message.Title: Just lost my whole retirement savings on AAPL
Message.Msg: Lost 30% of my IRA money after the crash in 2009. Dummie ole me, got out with 70% and went into 3 year TBs. So, when they matured in September, guess what I bought? Yep, AAPL. I watched it drop almost every day, but CNBC said it was going to $1000, so I decided to ride it out. BAD IDEA. Fortunately, my wife's IRA is in safer than safe, 30 year TBs. Unfortunately, she left with the kids in November after a big fight over money. I have nothing left now, AAPL and Marie got it all. I'm a laid off broker, and-no pun intended-BROKE. After my unemployment ran out 4 years I started looking. Anybody out there need a broker with 12 years experience in derrivatives? One time I had over $14 million to play with-my own money-and was responsible for 14% of all the profit my firm made in 2005. Hey, this is not a resume, or, maybe it is, I don't know. I know one thing for sure, when you lose as much as I have, Johnny Walker Red is a good ole friend. After 1/2 a bottle, IT DON"T MATTER! BOL to y'all still holding. If ya try options, don't end up like me. (:

Message.Title: New patent app takes on Amazon
Message.Msg: United States Patent Application 20130024908 Kind Code A1 Doman; Thomas E. ; et al. January 24, 2013 SYSTEM AND METHOD FOR APPLICATION-INTEGRATED INFORMATION CARD SELECTION Abstract A selector daemon can run in the background of a computer. Applications that are capable of processing information cards directly, without requiring the use of a card selector, can request the selector daemon to list information cards that satisfy security policy. Upon receiving such a request, selector daemon can determine the information cards available on the computer that satisfy the security policy, and can identify these information cards to the requesting application. The applications can then use the identified information cards in any manner desired, without having to use a card selector: for example, by requesting a security token based on one of the information cards directly from an identity provider. Inventors: Doman; Thomas E.; (Pleasant Grove, UT) ; Buss; Duane F.; (West Mountain, UT) ; Sanders; Daniel S.; (Orem, UT) ; Hodgkinson; Andrew A.; (Pleasant Grove, UT) ; Sermersheim; James G.; (Woodland Hills, UT) ; Norman; James M.; (Pleasant Grove, UT) Assignee: APPLE INC. Cupertino CA Serial No.: 619572 Series Code: 13 Filed: September 14, 2012 Current U.S. Class: 726/1 Class at Publication: 726/1 International Class: G06F 21/00 20060101 G06F021/00 Claims 1. A system, comprising: a computer; a memory in the computer; an application stored in the memory; and a selector daemon stored in the memory, the selector daemon including: a receiver to receive a security policy from the application; and an information card identifier to identify at least one information card on the computer that satisfies said security policy. Description RELATED APPLICATION DATA [0001] This application is a continuation of co-pending U.S. patent application Ser. January 24, 2013 AUTOMATED DETERMINATION OF APPLICABILITY AND VALUE OF DISCOUNTS FOR A PURCHASE ORDER Abstract A method for automatically determining applicability and value of any discounts for a purchase order from a client computer, the determinations being made by the client computer itself. In some embodiments, the client computer receives (from a server to which the order is being placed) coupon programming, determines applicability and value of discounts using the coupon programming, and sends discount information for an order to the server. The coupon programming may comprise a rule engine, implemented by rule programming, having one or more sets of rules and a processing relationship between the sets of rules and the rules in each set of rules. The rule engine may comprise a recursive rule program. In some embodiments, the applicability and value of any discounts for an order is determined by a server that receives the order, the determinations being made by using a rule engine implemented by rule programming. Message.Title: How Low Will APPL Fall.... $375....$350... $325....$300 or below?
Message.Msg: This stock seems definitely broken and is significantly over owned. Margin squeezes and calls against retail investors will continue to put significant downward pressure on Apple shares as they are losing market share in the lower end of the Smart Phone Sector and competitive pressures will continue to increase in this space and as a result compress profit margins going forward. The stock price beta and daily trading volatility will remain high and the road ahead will be quite bumpy and turbulent going forward. Uncertainty is never a good thing with investors today. Expectations are very high and shares are still priced for perfection, which is difficult to satisfy and achieve in this type of market. For now, I think it's prudent to stay on the sidelines and watch for a better entry point and a change in trends and investor sentiment.

Topic.Title: Steve Jobs is dead, and so is Apple's direction and vision.

Message.Msg: We should consider selling our stock, because it was only a matter of time… Critics have questioned how long Apple could hold up WITHOUT the leader who crafted the company in his vision. And now we know. That apology from Apple indicates more than a minor screw up or a #$%$ in the armor for the near trillion dollar company, it’s representative of the huge paradigm shift that has taken place at Apple. It is now painfully obvious that Apple CEO Tim Cook is not Steve Jobs. The press release disguised as an apology tells us all we need to know: "At Apple, we strive to make world-class products that deliver the best experience possible to our customers. With the launch of our new Maps last week, we fell short on this commitment.…we wanted to provide our customers with even better Maps including features such as turn-by-turn directions, voice integration, Flyover and vector-based maps. In order to do this, we had to create a new version of Maps from the ground up". Translation: "We tried to reinvent something without the help of our visionary leader and failed miserably. It’s back to the drawing board while the product that we hyped as our greatest invention fails miserably.You can now unlock the original practically for free via ebay". It’s now apparent that without Steve Jobs at the helm, mistakes are okay for Apple, as long as they are followed by an immediate and somewhat genuine apology. How many apologies did Steve Jobs ever offer? How many times did he ever release a product that was blatantly inferior to its predecessor?

Message.Title: Projected Earnings Decline of 15%
Message.Msg: Yahoo Finance Analyst Estimates are projecting an earnings decline of 15% for the March quarter. This is ridiculous. They must be basing it on what the CFO said on the conference call. Either way, this would be the first quarter in a long time when Apple earnings are projected lower year over year. Sure the P/E looks really low and hence the automatic thinking is to buy the stock. However, if projected earnings are declining rapidly, the stock will get dragged lower until Apple will blow the earnings again and show growth. Do your own DD. Check Analyst Estimates for AAPL under Yahoo Finance. This is a friendly advice from another Apple Long who doesn't want fellow Longs to lose more money.

Message.Title: Apple refuses to build a bigger phone. Shorts rejoice.
Message.Msg: The biggest thing i took from the conference call was Apple's refusal to offer more choices. Apple will lose half it's market share or more before they realize tens of millions of people want a bigger phone. Read the WSJ article about Apple losing its cool. In it a customer says the iphone just looks tiny compared to the Galaxy. So true. Phones, more now than ever are used for everything but phone calls. Sure, millions want a smaller phone, but millions more want a bigger phone. Here is a quote from the earnings call: Tim Cook - CEO: Bill, its Tim. The iPhone 5 offers as you know a new 4-inch Retina display which is the most advanced display in the industry, and no one comes close to matching the level of quality as the Retina display. It also provides a larger screen size for iPhone customers without sacrificing the one-headed ease-of-use that our customers love. So, we put a lot of thinking into screen size and believe we picked the right one. Is Tim Cook serious? No one comes close?? Lol When the 5s is released make sure you're short, as i foresee a 15-20% drop when they stick with the 4 inch screen. Further, i don't think they'll release a larger iphone until late 2014 after sales have dropped over 50%. The same thing happen to Rimm. They thought no one wanted a touch screen. When they realized they were wrong, it was far too late. They were finished. Apple, to a certain extent is going down the same road. Short any and all rallies for the foreseeable future. Short with impunity.

Topic.Title: Anybody (experienced) short under 440 or gonna short there??

Message.Msg: Too expensive a stock for me but I bought the $350 March puts at 40 cents. They are up over 50% in 2 days. I would at least stay away until the gap fills at around $420. Basic stock charting 101 says that when a stock gaps up big later down the road the gap fills. In January of last year there was a big gap up from $420 to about $450, leaving a hole/gap in the chart. Other than that there really isn't any indicator for a bottom on AAPL. Every indicator on the chart looks very bearish. And it's way below every moving average you could possibly use as a support line. So it's either round numbers as a bottom ($400, $350, etc.) or the gap at $420. To be safe I would not try to guess the bottom. I would wait until the bottom actually occurs and the chart starts to turn back around. And then buy on the way up. The 50 day moving average is at $532 (it is dropping fast though because the new calculations [today's closing price, yesterdays, tomorrow's] are bringing the average down. Long story short wait maybe wait until a clear breakout above the 50 day moving average. (You see what happened when AAPL fell below the 50 day moving average in October? That was a screaming sell indication and the price was $650 when this occurred.)

Topic.Title: Apple at almost 2 times next years cash snd people are telling u to sell that is blatant criminality

Message.Msg: Do yourself a favor and look at the press release. They have $ 137 Billion in Cash, cash equivalents and short and long term marketable securities. Basically, they have $137 Billion that is liquid. There are other notable figures that came out. 1. Inventories doubled from a year ago. This could be a good or bad thing depending on what that inventory actually consists of, but the fact that they have a 2-3 week delivery for the IMac it isn’t the one product that is declining in sales. 2. They gave back $4.5 billion in dividends and stock repurchases last quarter. They still have authorization to repurchase another $7.5 Billion over the next three years. I am not sure about the fine points of the authorization, but if they repurchase $7.5 Billion shares over the next few quarters and give a dividend of $2.5ish a quarter they will give back roughly $20 Billion to shareholders in FY13. 3. They increased their R&D by 33% to over a $1 Billion from Q1 '12. I am priced in at a decent price, but the fire sale still hurts. If you’re priced in over $600 I am sorry, but it may be better to cut your losses. Don’t just look at Yahoo finance, look at the numbers yourself and you may be able to sleep at night.

Message.Msg: Tony, If you go to Apple's investor relations website, you can access Apple's 1st 10Q financial report. Within this report it gives you a breakdown of Apple's $137.1B in cash & cash equivalents. Also, if you listen to the conference call, Oppenheimer states how much cash they have. Apple's cash increased $16B this qtr from $121B to $137.1B. Also, for the clueless, Apple has accrued $15B for tax repatriation on the $96B held oversees. You can also verify this in the 10Q report as deferred tax liabilities. There is so much misinformation on this board. Apple is hated right now. I don't know why, but I don't care, I am going to hold for years. If the price drops to $400, I am going to go all in. Apple is going to have $175B by the end of this year!

Topic.Title: need serious advise

Message.Msg: You made the mistake that a lot of investors make. When they see a disaster, like what happened after earnings, then they think it is a steal and buy in the next day. Only problem is the people that held through the disaster want any amount of money back so they all sell when the price goes up a little bit. That is what happened the other day. At the open it sores up and then plummets immediately. When the stock bombs like that, I wait a few days and watch it before considering something if I am on the sidelines like you were. Topic.Title: Tim Cook Please Throw Us a Life Line

Message.Msg: We are a trading Nation. With the hot heads in Congress, we will see a massive depression coming. I would say start trading & investing overseas. Our economy is driven by consumption, to the tune of 80% of GDP. Without a vibrant middle class, cutting expenses and QE forever, is a recipe for disaster. The top 5% won’t make up for the drag on the middle class that balancing the budged over the next 10 years will bring to our economy. You can be sure the very well off will not share the burden proportionally and they will not consume as the majority of our society did in previous decades. Soon the world biggest economies will figure that out too and abandon the US to stew in its own juices. So, yes, buy and sell and play the margins but at least be honest that nothing is free there is a cost to everything. What is being masked by the boy/girls in congress of either party is that it is their failure to make responsible choices over the last 50 years that has let us to massive deficits in this nation. For them to actually believe they are going to eliminate the deficit in 10 years is ludicrous. They’ll kill the Golden Goose doing it. We will be trading company stocks not on the USD. Probably in a basket of currencies and Gold. The big spenders will be other people. Sorry to be so pessimistic.

Message.Title: I learned a lesson about options
Message.Msg: Before earnings it was suggested to Sell JAn 2014 market price puts but hedged with mear term puts... The day after earnings, this trade was up $13 per option trade...Yesterday...the stock fell $10+, the Feb put ONLY went up $1.84 but the FEB put went up $4.65. Notice, stock down $10 yet the Jan 2014 $450 put is up $1.84...all the Jan 2014 puts are saying this sell-off is OVERDONE... NOw that original suggestion when AAPL was at $520 to sell the Jan 2014 $520 call and put for $147 but buy a $390 put...another profitable trade....to close out the sale of both options s $122...but the $390 put is ONLY up $3...so $147 - $122 + $3 = $28 per option trade...$28 means $2800 per option contracts. Notice how AAPL fell from $520 to $440 yet the $390 put only ran from $24 to $27...there is a lesson here

Topic.Title: why aapl is trading like a value stock

Message.Msg: Gross margins of 40 percent are too high for a hardware company. They are unsustainable and have to come down to the teens or lower. People payed more because they perceived them as better. I think we are past that now and that is why the stock is falling. So if margins go to 20% from the peak of 40% then what happens to earnings? They go in half. So the 13 per share they earned this quarter will go to less then 7. So if they earn 28 a share for the year and you put a 10 multiple on it then you get a 280 stock. That is what the sellers are frightened about. Personally, I wouldn't pay more than 300 for apple stock. Anything from 300 to 700 is just hype.

Topic.Title: PLEASE Help Me - I am Devastated! Need some advice.

Message.Msg: AAPL is not going under but they are slowing down and the negative publicity will accelerate the decline. It is too big to return to its quirky niche product days and competition will force them to lower their prices. As customer demand declines, the wireless carriers will put unbearable pressure on AAPL to reduce their prices even more. AAPL, not being as fully integrated in hardware as a Samsung or a software powerhouse like GOOG, is less able to respond. Once the price wars begin in ernest, margins will decline precipitously and AAPL will continue to lose pricing power. They will use their cash hoard foolishly to buy smaller more innovative companies, but will suffer the same fate as CSCO and MSFT has with this strategy. Look at their stock performance over the past few years as a guide to where AAPL is headed. I hate to see that happen because AAPL has been a great trading stock. But it will happen. People with blind faith in AAPL will continue to lose their capital as the market adjusts to the new reality. A 50% initial decline is quite normal, in situations like this, so $350 is a realistic target that should be achieved over the next few weeks/months.

Topic.Title: HOW CAN ALL THESE HIGHLY PAID ANALYSTS BE SO WRONG????

Message.Msg: first of all .. never listen to an analyst and think on what just happened. Apple made a lot of money and sold 48M iphones even with a constrained supply chain. We bought several phones at Christmas (AT&T Contract subsidized) and had to wait several weeks to even get them. Even with this, Apple sold a ton of phones. I heard one analyst say anything with a 5 in it (for predicting phone sales) is good; anything with a 4 is bad. What kind of logic is that ... pick some random delineation point? Apple was just fine for the quarter but missed some arbitrary targets? the real issue is that Hedge Funds are worried about their future business slowing and looking out years from now (no one can tell). If it stays at 11+ EPS every quarter, then it will be no issue, If earnings start to slow (say 10 or 9), then obviously the P/E will have to adjust which brings the stock valuation down. This is why the big boys are dumping some of their positions until they can really see what is happening. Remember many bought when the stock was sub-150 so they are still making profits. What Apple needs now is new products to ensure growth or growth oversees to ease concern about future EPS. No analyst can predict that ... it is wait and see and decide which side you want to bet on. I think Apple will produce a lower price phone in China, India, etc. to compete with Samsung, Nokia, etc. in those markets and to keep those companies from making too much money for the R&D war-chests. Time will tell ... I like Apple at these levels.

Message.Title: ITune monney making machine takes 0.33 cent of the 99C
Message.Msg: It generally breaks down like this: Right off the top, Apple takes ~$0.30 from that $0.99 sale. Of the $0.69 left, half goes to the label. The other half goes to the publisher once the label's initial investment in the artist has been recouped. Generally speaking, a label invests somewhere in the neighborhood of $300-500k for artists. And with digital sales being what they are these days, that means an artist really only starts getting paid after they've sold nearly half a million downloads. To put this into perspective, the most downloaded song ever on iTunes ("I Gotta Feeling" by the Black Eyed Peas) has sold 6 million copies. So you can imagine that most artists don't see much revenue from iTunes sales, given that their sales numbers are significantly lower than the most popular artists. Indie artists fare a bit better, but not by much. That being said, Apple's not the worst offender in royalties paid to artists, though some argue that 30% is a pretty hefty fee for processing a digital transaction. Below is a great visualization for some additional insight on how much artists get paid per additional distribution method.

Message.Title: Think about it
Message.Msg: Chinese New Year begins Feb 10th. How easy would it be for AAPL to produce Iphone 3 with a chip that is compatible with China Mobile's network? So easy that production of these units could not be noticed by prying eyes. The ASP and the margins on these models would benefit both China Mobile and AAPL by selling a handset that most Chinese could afford, and if not, could finance with the credit facility AAPL recently announced. AAPL's margins on Iphone 3's are near or above the 50% range. With 700,000,000 subscribers, AAPL could easily penetrate 20% of the market, or 140,000,000 new subscribers. If AAPL priced the Iphone 3 at $200, that would result in $280 billion in sales, and at 50% margin, $140 billion in profit. Now if China Mobile demanded a cut from AAPL of say 20%, AAPL would still clear $100 billion in profit. And what about ecosystem profits? Profits from financed Iphone sales? People seem to have forgotten that IPad mini began selling in China last Friday. Naysayers would have you believing that NO Chinese desire an AAPL product. Culturally Chinese New Year in the biggest time where "the best of the best" gifts are purchased. Additionally, Chinese social standards frown upon buying anything but the best. Giving a gift of lesser quality is a major insult. Now if AAPL announces a pact with China Mobile China New Years day, what kind of impact would sales during Q2 have on EPS targets? A 40-50 beat would perhaps be modest. AAPL's production costs will also lower as yields and constraints are resolved. That also means higher margins for Q2 earnings reporting. The other monster in the room is India that has a population 3/4 the size of China. While I am no Cook fan, the master of the supply chain, AAPL has not lost the engineering talent to produce the next gadget that none of us knew we needed, or wanted. Content acquisition, cloud, iTV, and the potential for AAPL to buy a satellite company and run their own wireless network, capturing all that data plan income

Message.Title: A solid holding at these levels
Message.Msg: Post-Earnings Stock Analysis: 3 Best Buys By Daniel Sparks - January 25, 2013 | Tickers: AAPL, COH, GOOG | 1 Comment Daniel is a member of The Motley Fool Blog Network -- entries represent the personal opinions of our bloggers and are not formally edited. Digging through this week's post-earnings mess, I've dug up three investment-worthy stocks: Apple (NASDAQ: AAPL), Google (NASDAQ: GOOG), and Coach (NYSE: COH). Apple Apple's stock has plummeted over 10% since it announced earnings on Wednesday. Despite the horrific drop in the stock price, there was plenty of great news: Year over year revenue and iPhone units sold increased 27% and 29%, respectively (numbers adjusted to reflect the shorter quarter in FQ1 2013). Net income was less impressive, declining slightly from $13.87 per share in the year-ago quarter to $13.81 per share. Furthermore, a few key items were buried in the debate on the company's financials. For instance, iCloud users were up about 200%, from 85 million in the year-ago quarter to 250 million. Plus, iTunes users topped 500 million, adding a nice $2.1 billion to the bottom line. Apple CEO Tim Cook refers to Apple's cloud services as a "strategy for the next decade." After the sell-off, Apple has a nice dividend yield of 2.4%. Even better, the stock is priced for zero growth despite average analyst estimates of double-digit growth in earnings in 2013. Operating on such a large scale already, Apple is no longer a growth stock. But it's a solid, profitable mega-cap with a nice yield that should serve investors well for years to come. Google

Message.Title: Conservative AAPL options strategy for those still Bullish
Message.Msg: Here is a conservative option strategy for those bullish on AAPL and wanting to play the recent price action. Buy long dated deep in the money call ( e.g. oct $350) and sell an at or just out of the money call with same expiry (e.g. Oct $450) ... At Fri closing price, this would have cost you ~$6600 and if AAPL can get above $450 by Oct expiration, your positions would be worth $10K for a gain of ~$3400 or 50% .... Plus if you already own shares of AAPL, the money you collect from selling the $450 call (~$3400) can help be a hedge against any further short term fall in AAPL stock. This trade won't lose money unless AAPL falls below $405 ... ($439 close price - $34 from sale of call = $405) Thoughts?

Topic.Title: HOW CAN ALL THESE HIGHLY PAID ANALYSTS BE SO WRONG????

Message.Msg: This doesn't explain the 35% YTD? Samsung does not control smartphone sales in the U.S. ... See info below. Only on a global basis because Chinese, Indians, etc can't pay $700 for a phone. Apple’s (NASDAQ:AAPL) iPhone continues to be mighty in the U.S., but its growth internationally is slowing, an analysis by Raymond James analyst Tavis McCourt has found. According to McCourt’s calculations, combined fourth-quarter iPhone sales at AT&T (NYSE:T) and Verizon (NYSE:VZ) were up 25 percent to 14.8 million units, while all other smartphone sales declined by 2 percent at the two carriers. From a market share basis, Apple took 74 percent share of smartphones at these two carriers against 69 percent a year ago. “Assuming modest success at Sprint (NYSE:S),” the analyst said iPhone sell-through estimate outside of the U.S. could be put at 29.2 million. This would represent a 35 percent year-over-year growth, or a deceleration from the 40 percent growth of the third quarter.

Message.Msg: When a stock like Apple slides like this, the peanut gallary gets incredibly noisy. Suddenly, the stock price is dictating the fundamentals if you listen to all the negative buzz out there. The slide could continue at least to $425 imo, but its getting near the stick a fork in 'em level if it goes into the $300s. Hedge funds are key here - do they continue to sell shares under pressure down here or do whales not already in decide to get in. The problem with a truly over loved stock is that you run out of potential buyers unless a big drop occurs. The selling keeps forcing more selling as the hedge funds get crushed for now under negative mojo. The technicals are horrific.

Message.Title: ASR. Lower stock price benefits Apple and longs until August 2013
Message.Msg: In August 2012, the Company entered into an accelerated share repurchase program (“ASR”) with a financial institution to purchase up to $1.95 billion of the Company’s common stock in 2013. In exchange for an up-front payment of $1.95 billion, the financial institution committed to deliver a number of shares during the ASR’s purchase period, which ends later in 2013. The total number of shares ultimately delivered, and therefore the average price paid per share, will be determined at the end of the purchase period based on the volume weighted average price of the Company’s stock during that period. In the first quarter of 2013, 2,582,782 shares were initially delivered to the Company. This does not represent the final number of shares to be delivered under the ASR. These shares were retired and accounted for as a reduction to shareholders’ equity in the Company’s Condensed Consolidated Balance Sheet. The Company accounted for the ASR as a repurchase of common stock for purposes of calculating earnings per share and as a forward contract indexed to its own common stock which met all of the applicable criteria for equity classification, and, therefore, was not accounted for as a derivative instrument.

Topic.Title: 100% rule about options

Message.Msg: This is what I have done. But to say you can NEVER lose money (unrealized loss) is not correct. Whether or not you overall net a gain or loss selling covered calls fully depends on what call strike and expiration you sell, and where the stock is trading then. Yes, the premium from shorting calls is yours to keep no matter what happens. However, the stock can definitely fall faster than one can hedge a stock long position selling calls. Only sales of deep in the money calls then which are initially nuetral in premium recieved would now give very effective hedge on this falling knive stock price.

Topic.Title: Projected EPS of 10.44 for March quarter

Message.Msg: Edison, I should have clarified. I meant that a China mobile deal, even if with lower margin iPhones, could drop the average GM%, but the additional billions in net margin $ will increase the EPS. I agree that the mix is heavily weighted with the iPhone GM%. In my profession, I often deal with this dilemma. Do you dilute your GM margin % with lower margin work/sales, but increase your GM and net margin $ in the process, or do you go after business that keeps your GM margin % high, but you lose sales and market in the process? The fact is, yes, the iPhone will not be able to maintain the ridiculous margin % forever, but if you can make it up with more volume, who cares about the %? I believe this why the stock price has cratered. The conference call was a disaster. Wall Street wants Apple to diversify with bigger screen phones, and cheaper phones to slow Samsung down. They have the same fears that you mentioned. If your GM% is shrinking, you must make it up with increased revenues, and a mix of new iPhones would do just this.

Topic.Title: Lets Look at some facts.. And please only rational people respond .. Short or long .. But bashers please take a coffee brake

Message.Msg: Revenue has nothing to do with margins. Last quarter revenue was up 18% yet earnings were flat. Yes an extra week would have added to the EPS, but most quarters are 13 weeks, but, and try to grasp this, Apple released the iPhone5 earlier this year so while the quarter was shorter the iPhone5 sold in the US for the entire quarter and in 100 other countries during the quarter. There are NO new countries to release the phone in this quarter. IE they stacked the deck for last quarter and packed more sales into it than the year before by releasing their biggest product earlier. Are you being deliberately obtuse? THE ISSUE (emphasis added so you stop looking backward) is next quarter's growth and what it means for the FUTURE (ie the IMPORTANT part). REVENUE GROWTH in the second quarter from 2011 to 2012 was 55%, but from 2012 to 2013 it projects to just 7% Can you understand that is a HUGE slowdown? EPS during that time will drop significantly as well due to the lower margins? Margins that most predict are not done compressing. So try to think in the future. Revenue growth is SLOWING, margins are getting SMALLER, new products like the mini and a cheaper phone will have even WORSE margins so while they will help revenue to an extent (ie the extent they don't cannibalize sales of the more expensive versions) it will require significantly more revenue to keep EPS from dropping. Obviously next quarter they will fail to do that for the first time in forever. Can you also not understand that by the end of last quarter supply was not an issue for the iPhone5 and in fact they had EXCESS inventory? Supply did impact the iPad Mini and iMAC, but GOING FORWARD it isnt an issue and yet second projections show very little growth.

Do not buy. However, if AAPL does make that big dip-trip, and manages to close above Friday's close, (still wait it out for Tuesday's action). This could be a sign of capitulation, but it hasn't been confirmed until Tuesday is watched. On Tuesday, if AAPL gaps up, above Monday's close, buy at the open- watch pre-market. You need confirmation, that this downtrend is over, and it will take Monday's action and Tusday's action to confirm. I know what you are thinking, if AAPL gaps down and goes lower 10-15 bucks Monday, I'm buying. Why? It may go another 10-15 lower Tuesday. Message.Title: Cramer's 'Mad Money' Recap: Apple $1,000 Not Half-Baked (Final) April 3, 2012
Message.Msg: NEW YORK (TheStreet) -- Rational or irrational? That's the trillion-dollar question when it comes to Piper Jaffray's prediction that Apple (AAPL_) could see its shares top $1,000. Jim Cramer told his "Mad Money" TV show viewers Tuesday that it's perfectly rational for investors to doubt this bold target, but after they do the math, $1,000 a share may not seem all that illogical. See if (AAPL) is in our portfolio Cramer said that analyzing Apple, a stock he owns for his charitable trust Action Alerts PLUS, is just like analyzing any other stock. One must first determine how much the company will earn as earnings, then multiply that number by how much the markets are willing to pay for those earnings. According to Piper Jaffray, Apple will earn $51 a share by 2013 and up to $80 a share by 2015, a solid assessment, said Cramer, given the company's dominance in smart phones, tablets and computers. But are investors really willing to pay $1,000 a share for those earnings? Cramer said this is where the research gets interesting. According to Piper Jaffray's research, Apple will be shaving hundreds of millions of dollars worth of market cap from its rivals over the next two years. Yet when analyzing the company to achieve its $1,000 price target, the Piper analyst still values Apple's earnings at just 12 times, less than that of the competition it will continue to crush. Cramer said that Apple, of course, deserves a multiple far greater than that of the competition. But shares have historically always been valued as the underdog, he noted, so Piper Jaffary just extended that trend into its analysis. And that's why, he said, thinking of Apple as a $1,000 stock is not "irrationally exuberant" as some have claimed, but likely a foregone conclusion.

Message.Title: How to calculate Apples true stock price value. I came up with 681. The formula is here. Do your own calc.
Message.Msg: Step 1 Check the company's most recent quarterly report (10-Q) and look up their earnings per share (EPS). You'll find two figures: The number of shares of stock the company issued and the earnings. To calculate the EPS by hand, divide the earnings by the number of shares. You'll quickly realize that you can't compare Company A to Company B based on price alone, even if they're trading at similar prices. The number of shares matters when you calculate earnings. Step 2 Divide the the company's price-per-share by its EPS to get the price-to-earnings ratio, also called the P/E ratio. This number can stump new investors. But it's part of an investing vocabulary and helps you come to terms with the difference between price and value. The P/E defines how much each dollar of earnings costs the investor. You pay almost twice as much for a dollar of earnings for a company with a P/E of 85 than for a company with a P/E of 45. Step 3 Factor in the sales and you have another measure of value. Divide the share price by the total sales and you have the price-to-sales ratio. Keep this in mind when a company catches your investment eye. Once considered an old-fashioned and dated metric, the P/S ratio has been dusted off and used to cut through the fluff of earnings statements. It's risky and difficult for companies to fudge sales (revenue) numbers. Historically, companies with low P/S ratios beat companies with low P/Es. Step 4 Include the company's growth rate and calculate the PEG rate. Take the P/E and divide it by the current growth rate. For example, FatWallet Company has a P/E of 67 and a growth rate of 25 percent. Its PEG is 67/25 = 2.68. According to MSN Money, stocks with PEGs higher than 1.0 are trading above their growth rate; those with PEGs around 1.0 match their projections.

Message.Title: Why a China Mobile deal solves the growth problem with these numbers
Message.Msg: China Mobile has a little over 700 mil subs but only 12% 3G or 82 mil. Apple has from 12 to 16% of the subs on each of the other two networks in China so it's reasonable that Apple can get as much from a China Mobile deal. A conservative estimate would be around 10 mil mors subs added to the total in the first full qtr apple is offered. The kicker is this gets apple's foot in the door as 3G is a growth area where additions look to be from 20 to 30% per year and maybe more. Looking at China Mobile alone if Apple can maintain their 12 to 16% share of the total 3G market they can get anywhere from 30 to 50 mil more subs per year. An addition of 10 mil subs to the 47 mil sold this past qtr would have given Apple a blowout in Revs and earnings. The conversation about apple would be totally different. Now if apple can offer a lower cost phone to the entire over 1 billion subscriber base on all the Chinese carriers we're looking at a market that will easily surpass the US and if you add India where Apple has minimum exposure we once again see double difit growth per qtr. and that's without any new sources of revenue.

Message.Msg: There may be more pain to come....but I think you have suffered most of the pain to this point. I own shares at $99...I saw them go all the way up to $705 and did not sell. Wished I did. But you and I are in the same spot believe it or not. Is this the best place right now to grow your money back to what you have lost so far and is it the best place for me to make money from this point forward. In other words, what other options to we have to make money...because clearly this isn't the only place. Hopefully, this is not a large position for you as a percentage of your total portfolio. From my reading of your message, it appears as it might be...."heart wrenching". If it is, then lesson learned - not to sound mean...but I had to learn that lesson myself - you just cannot bank on one stock. So, here is what I do now. I trade UPRO and SPXU pretty much everyday...at least right now. Both are 3X ETFs on the S&P. Yes, that is alot of risk...but wait. AAPL, by the way is about 2% of the holdings . Today, the direction of the S&P is up,up, up. Currently, and I am talking recently, the S&P hits its daily low sometime around 10:30 am to 11:30 am EST...not always. At this point, I buy UPRO (because I think S&P is going up)...now...I don't go all in...I use about 10% to 20% of my account (in fairness...this is risk money...wouldn't change my lifestyle if I lost it...but emotionally...would be very difficult...I would want to "make it back"...this sounds like where you are). I then place a stop....you got to have a stop!!!!!....if I buy at $100, I would set my stop at $98....just knowing this ETF "today"...that is a safe distance to let the trade cook...now, I am looking at getting out by the end of the day. I will take a profit of say 50 cents to up to $2 per share. The S&P just keeps going up "today". Seriously, I have not lost on one single trade in 2013. This takes discipline!!!!! somedays I don't trade!...I make $1K to $2K per week currently.

Message.Msg: Whereas compressing margins can be a concern if Revenues remain constant or decrease, they mean less if you can continue to grow Revenues enough to increase EPS. The catalyst for that would be new products (I-must have new gizmos) or increasing market share in markets where you are lagging. Insert China, Brazil & India as fertile fields for Revenue growth and you can see how compressed margins become of lesser concern. Let's say tha it costs you $100 to manufacture an I-widget. If you can sell 100 I-widgetswith a 50% markup or sell 500 widgets with 20% markup, which would you prefer. The former gives you a profit of $5,000 whereas the latter case gives you $10,000. I would embrace compressed margins on specific products if I knew it would increase market share. On the new OMG products, they should be able to maintain higher margins for the first couple of years.

Topic.Title: Options help... please be nice.

Message.Msg: Ok, no problem. Look I think you will be fine. I would look to sell 5% otm ( out of the money) calls on a weekly basis and trail them. If the stock shoots up you will need to roll them up and out a week keeping that 5% buffer against the stock. Example, on Monday, you might want to sell 1 of the Feb 460 calls expiring that week. The premium may not be that much but it will give you a little income. Plus you have the div in mid Feb ( 2.65). Then is the stock is say 470 by the end of the week, you will need to buy them back and sell the 500 strike the following week. Best case scenario the stock closes 460 and you keep the premium. The one thing with Apple is they at anytime can do something that will catch people by surprise, meaning they are holding alot of powder here. There are a dozen or so catalysts that could send this off to the races. My advice is wait a few weeks and see how the stock plays out. Please keep in mind, the media and the analysts are 100% responsible for this mess. The media treated this company like it was some high P/E stock and the analysts all seem to think they can come out with numbers that if they are not met, than they have the final say. As of now, Apple has 140 bill in cash. They make a billion a week. If the past is any indicator I would not count them out in terms of innovation. Lastly, this is the cheapest tech stock out there in terms of growth and p/e multiple. Do not let the dopes on this board tell you otherwise. Best of luck

Topic.Title: Options help... please be nice.

Message.Msg: It will be easier to just show you an example. Lets say you own 100 shares and you want to sell March call. So you sell to open 1 contract of March $470 call for $7.50 which nets you $750 minus fees. Let suppose stock rebounded to $480 on March expiration. On that day, your call will worth a little over $10, maybe $10.50. If you want to close it, you will need to come up with $1050 plus fees to buy it back with a buy to close order. I don't like to buy back covered call for a loss. What I will do in this case is to roll the covered call out and up to a later date contract. To do this, you can issue a two legged order. First leg buy to close the March 470, second leg sell to open another covered call at a higher strike price a few months out. The key here is to pick the second leg far enough that will offset the cost of buying back the March 470, preferably net you some cashes. So if March $480 costs $10.50 to close out, you want to sell the second leg for at least $11 to $12.

Message.Title: Getting Scary
Message.Msg: US Federal Reserve is reporting a major deposit withdrawal from the nation’s bank accounts. The financial system hasn’t seen such a massive fund outflow since 9/11 attacks. The first week of January 2013 has seen $114 billion withdrawn from 25 of the US’ biggest banks, pushing deposits down to $5.37 trillion, according to the US Fed. Financial analysts suggest it could be down to the Transaction Account Guarantee insurance program coming to an end on December 31 last year and clients moving their money that is no longer insured by the government.

Message.Title: The Microsoft lesson, the parallel to AAPL
Message.Msg: )Microsoft topped dec.1999 at $60. -The price fall back into the range of 38.2%-67.7% of the top. -It lost a max. of $39 from the top, exactly 1 year after breaking down from the top. -Since then, all 12 years long, it oscillates between $21 and $37 range. -On the way down, MSFT dropped in 5 months first to 50%, rebounded in 2 months to 18%, and the then dropped to bottom in 5 more months, to 38.2%. 2)AAPL topped at $700. If the above parallel holds: -AAPL should fall in a year into $440-264 range, and stay there for the next 12 years. -on the way down, currently AAPL is at 5 months decline, it is time for the first rebound bottom at $440, and should rebound in the next 2 months 18%, close to $520. From that point we might expect AAPL price to fall for 5 months, bottoming sept.2013 at $264. If it follows the MSFT pattern. The psycology is pretty much the same.

Message.Title: One Fallacy of AAPL margins
Message.Msg: When a company has lower gross margins due to competitive reasons, 9 times out 10 it will show up in unit selling price. That is to say, the company has to discount on price. There was some small evidence in the Holliday quarter that iPhone 5s were discounted but it appeared to be the particular retailers promotion and not an Apple concession. Walmart comes to mind. Great marketing on the part of Walmart, but not indicative of any discounting on the part of apple. Remember, Walmart only ran the promotion in select physical stores and probably only had very limited inventory in those stores (at most 10 to 15 phones per location). What would you prefer? Tens of millions in running an additional national ad campaign or a small iPhone promotion that would get just as much press, as many people to your website, and as many people in your stores. So there was no credible evidence that apple discounted the iPhone 5. In fact there was evidence of supply constraints. This all means that any margin compression due to the iphone 5 was most likely not due to competitive reasons because as I said above, we usually see that in selling price discounts. What we did know before earnings was that the iPhone 5 would have lower margins due to direct material cost and other overhead fixed type cost due new design and form factor and new production that the iPhone 4S did not have associated with it. With this in mind, the arguments that margin compression is an indication of apple stumbling at the feet of android is muted especially given the fact that apple sold more iPhones year over year and that they sold more iPhone 5 than 4 s from a year ago. That is to say, they grew. I am apple supertramp and I am Steve

Topic.Title: Options help... please be nice.

Message.Msg: You will need cash to take long call assignment. It is the same as you are buying 100 shares at $400. In general, there is no reason to take in-money long call assignment because you will loss all time values as soon as the calls are exercised. You will be better off selling the calls before expiration. If for some reasons the calls become illiquid (ask/bid spread getting wide), which can happen if calls are getting deeply in money just before expiration, and you don't have cash to take the assignment. There are two ways to deal with it. You can call your broker and instruct them to do a cashless exercise. Your broker will exercise your calls and immediately sell the shares at the market price. Or you can lock in your profit by shorting the same number of shares before expiration. You can than use the assigned shares to cover the short position and keep the profits. I prefer using shorts to lock in profit because I have full control of the price. Sometimes it is difficult to control what price the booker sells your shares in a cashless exercise. You can exercise any call at any time. But why would you want to exercise an out-of-money call? It will be cheaper to just buy the shares.

Message.Title: Apple shifting its guidance to stop being blamed for "missing" analyst expectations
Message.Msg: Friday, January 25, 2013, 08:11 pm Apple shifting its guidance to stop being blamed for "missing" analyst expectations By Daniel Eran Dilger This week, Apple announced plans to change the way it outlines guidance, an effort apparently intended to thwart excessively enthusiastic analyst expectations that have resulted in a series of "misses" ultimately blamed upon the company itself. "In recent years," Apple's chief financial officer Peter Oppenheimer noted in his prepared comments in the company's earnings call, "our guidance reflected a conservative point estimate of results every quarter that we had reasonable confidence in achieving. "Going forward, we plan to provide a range of guidance that reflects our belief of what we are likely to achieve. While we cannot forecast with complete accuracy, we believe we are likely to report within the range of guidance we provide. Therefore, for the March quarter, we're providing revenue guidance of between $41 billion and $43 billion compared to $39.2 billion in the year ago quarter." Fool me once, Can't get fooled again For years, Apple has offered forward looking guidance outlining the minimum performance that company executives were reasonably confident they could reach over the coming quarter. As the company's performance has accelerated over the past several years of rapidly increasing sales of iPods and then iPhones, iPads and new Macs, Apple has consistently trampled its own guidance, resulting in the cynical perception that the company's forward looking figures were excessively conservative, to the point where critics began describing them as "sandbagging." Sandbagging figuratively suggests an effort to misrepresent one's own abilities early on in order to throw off one's competition. The term is often applied to billiard, chess or poker players who deceptively play under their true skill level in order to fool opponents into betting against them in a subsequent, higher stakes game. While Apple...

Topic.Title: One Fallacy of AAPL margins

Message.Msg: I could go on about the margins whether its the known iPad mini margin compression (competition) or the unknown extent of the iMac launch, but outside of every thing that can be easily and logically explained, there remains little to no evidence that competitive pressures are materially negatively affecting Apples business. Now, no question Android is dominating market share, and no doubt this industry going forward is a game of ecosystems, but honestly answer me this, is Apple doing such a bad job serving its current customers that they will, in a material way, jump ship to Android (especially given switching cost)? I think the answer to that at present is no. Besides Apple doing a bad job serving its customers, for Android to materially switch iPhone customers it would have to demonstrate something demonstrable different than the iPhone. I personally don't see that, but you can make up your own minds ( I do see screen size possibly especially for people who use their smart phones to totally replace or supplant a pc and/or tablet). Keep in mind that Premium Android phones sell for similar price to iPhone, so price is not really a materially differentiating factor. iPhone outsold S3. In closing, I do believe Apple will address the screen size and price point issues, but for now there is no compelling reason to rush that. The barriers to exit are high for the apple Eco system and the learning curve remains low. It's sticky. The barriers to exist are low for Android (my opinion) and the learning curve is high ( my opinion). If I'm right, then any time Apple decides it wants more market share then it can go out and get it. For now, the numbers don't suggest they need to panic or react.

Message.Title: What will be the near term low for Apple - my best guess now is anywhere between
Message.Msg: $430 and $360. I was proved wrong on friday when the stock couldn't hold $440. The last 2-3 minutes of trading were very disturbing - it clearly looked like someone or some trading program traded through the best bid/ask and sold a few shares down at 435. Could have been a pushed the wrong button error because the stock was holding in well in the low-mid 440s on good volume. But i suspect it's coming from pressure to take the stock lower near term. On a technical basis the charts look terrible. There is good medium term support at the $420 level with a possible low at $404, the medium range 200 day mvg average. The long term 50day mvg average would have the stock hit $380, but if it went that low it could drive through that and take it down as low as $360 where there is excellent support for the stock. It looks like analysts have now lowered their earnings for this year to a revised consensus $42.50 from $48. At $440 a share, with 939mil shares outstanding, the stock has a forward PE of 10.35. If you factor out the cash of $137bil as of 12/31/12, ie., current market cap at 440 equals $413.16bil minus $137.1bil cash equals $276.06bil and using consensus est. of $42.5, the PE ex cash at 440 is 6.91, a bit lower than MSFT's current PE ex cash. If it dropped to $360, the PE ex cash would then be 5.03. Although the chart would suggest that the downward momentum is such that we must hit 380 and go through it a bit, i do find it hard to believe that the company that as of today is the most profitable on the planet will actually trade down to a PE ex cash of 5, but it could happen. What might stop the slide and help the stock put in a low in say the 420 to 440 range. Two possibilities in the near term in my view - to be continued

Message.Title: MICROSOFT's 15 PE Valuation
Message.Msg: There is a financial article out today asking "if AAPL is the next MSFT". Pointing out how MSFT stock hit a peak in the year 2000, then went down, and then despite earnings went up over the next decade, MSFT just stayed about the same for years. THE COMPARISON IS NOT GOOD, misses several things. First, MSFT stock when it hit its peak was a 75 PE Ratio. Its now a 15 PE Ratio. Apple today is a 10 - 11 PE Ratio, already more depressed in valuation than MSFT was at when it was way up and also even now. When Apple stock was at its peak $704 last Fall, it didn't even have a 20 PE, not even close to MSFT's 75 PE at peak. Second thing that article is missing, is MSFT in the early 2000s paid a huge one-time Cash Return of Capital to shareholders, I seem to recall it was something like $30 per share. Apple's been stingy with dividends to shareholders so far. Meantime, Apple's so-called recent "weak quarter" (which was 29% growth in IPHONES sold and 49% in IPADS and was its highest quarterly profit ever), along with its recent stock price plunge, means AAPL stock is very undervalued vs. slower growing MSFT's 15 PE.

Message.Title: Hey Cook and Iger: TIME FOR A MONSTROUS SPECIAL DIVIDEND
Message.Msg: What a great time for a special dividend of $30 per share. Reasons to do that? 1. They began the Q with ample domestic cash for that even before considering the what, call it $15B+/- of incremental cash flow generation for the quarter. They can always bring cash back from offshore as the deferred tax piece has already been reflected in the financials -- it is a matter of relieving the deferred tax liability account and wiring the funds, not an earnings hit. 2. It would send a message about the new militancy of Cook's willingness to protect employee morale and demonstrate new sophistication on capital management. Incidentally, it would decisively F over the #$%$ saying AAPL is the new dell or msft or RIMM (or any other companies the idiots like Cramer and the gumptards here reference as the reset/no growth aapl). Apparently none of them understand the deltas on extra week, improving margins guided for March vs Dec Q, solid increase in guided revs for march yoy; or that AAPL really shouldn't be viewed as a 5x earnings stock like Cramer, Grundlach and other clowns -- even Misek now -- suggest is coming. 3. The tax noise/advantage of 3% if they had done it last year is over for individuals, but anyone who has been/remianed long for more than 3 months without hedge offsets has unrealized losses to reverse and those will largely evaporate with a solid jolt to the stock down here. I think almost no retail account would object (as if that matters) and EVERY PM I KNOW STILL LONG THE SHARES WOULD APPLAUD THE ACTION. It is not well understood, but the hedge fund and other players benefitting from "carried interest" deferrals are only paying cap gains taxes anyway. 4. Fav press would help staff morale too, be good for the BOD and Tim's reputations, and ensure AAPL never again finds itself subject to such a ridiculous and undefended attack by pot-smoking bond managers or anyone else with fleeting swagger walking into the gelding operations facility. LOL

Topic.Title: AAPL WILL BOUNCE MONDAY THEN GET HAMMERED WITH SELLING

Message.Msg: I agree. That's why I mentioned to someone earlier that you don't want to buy until a trend reversal confirmation is had. At the earliest, that will be Tuesday for a trend reversal confirmation. I know people are going to want to buy if AAPL drops 10-15 on Monday morning. I say wait Monday out regardless of what happens. As people who bought at 450 can attest, no confirmation was given on Friday to enter this stock. Basically, you need to see a close above Friday's close on Monday, then watch pre-market Tuesday for an open above Monday's close, then you can buy the open on Tuesday. If on Tuesday, AAPL opens lower than Monday's close, (and Mondays' close is lower than Friday's), you need to wait until Wednesday and watch for the same thing you watched for on Monday. And so on. Patience

Topic.Title: What will be the near term low for Apple - my best guess now is anywhere between

Message.Msg: The first is that the BOD takes decisive action that is announced early next week to stop the slide. I know they were scheduled to meet soon but i don't know the date. Someone is posting saying it will be on sunday - that would be great if true but who really knows. If they raised the dividend from $10.60 to $20, it seems it could be done easily given the current cash on hand and the cash currently being generated each quarter. A $20 dividend at 440 would provide a yield of 4.54percent. As a comparison, other large company's current yields are as follows: MSFT 3.3%, INTC 4.294%, IBM 1.659%, PG 3.06%, XOM 2.486%. In an instant, AAPL would have a dividend yield higher than every one of those stocks and such action I believe would not only put a floor under the stock but could unleash a sharp rally in the shares . At $500 a share with a $20 dividend, the yield would still be a very high %4, higher than all of those listed except INTC. If a dividend increase was announced along with a significant buyback plan, this could really turn the stock around on a dime and i would hazard a guess that the stock could easily return to the $500 range. What other possibility could stem the tide - to be continued

Topic.Title: AAPL WILL BOUNCE MONDAY THEN GET HAMMERED WITH SELLING

Message.Msg: Even if AAPL closes up $40 on Monday, you wait until Tuesday at earliest to buy. A $40 upward close is not a confirmation of a buy. It could be a hundred reasons, shorts covering, new investors people thinking its low???? That's exactly correct. If it closes up $40 on Monday, and it closes down $5.00 on Tuesday, that's not a buy confirmation. It could close down 20 on Wednesday, the down $5 bucks Tuesday is a wait for Wednesday signal. On Wednesday, after the $5 dip on Tuesday, you would watch the pre-market on Wednesday, and if AAPL opens lower than Tuesday's close, wait, if AAPL opens lower Wednesday than Tuesday's close set your buy limit order at Tuesday's close and let the market come to you. Don't chase the price below Tuesday's close thinking you're getting a better deal than some folks on Monday or Tuesday did. Here's the thing. The $40 up move Monday, signalled a possible buy for Tuesday. But certain benchmarks must be viewed for confirmation of a buy.

Message.Msg: The other possibility is if an analyst at one of the big WS firms like Goldman were to put out a note saying that they thought the selling was way overdone given that the company is still growing, albeit much more slowly than two years ago. Such an action, i believe could also put a stop to the selling in the stock such that we might hold a low in the 430 range, but ultimately we would need to see some significant announcement on the dividend and or buyback to get the stock moving higher, in my view. I think the concern of long term value players looking at the company is the sustainability of its earnings flow. AAPL's revenues and earnings have only been at these incredible levels for really less than two years. They would prefer to see a longer track record. Growth investors we are told by those reviewing SEC quarterly filings have been leaving the stock in larger numbers. The funny thing is though, for quite a while now AAPL never reached a growth multiple. Topic.Title: Let me help you sheep

Message.Msg: Reading past the third line of that was like chewing on cat litter. But I did it anyway. No innovation? Slow store traffic? Those are the comments of one with no information and dead wrong. AAPL has now done a S job articulating a simple point to the analysts: FY street for making us look bad when we are kicking butt on innovation, new product rollouts to new markets, opening up new LTE carriers around the world (study the 36 new carriers opened last week alone), all new product line up and new os, aapl stores packed and setting sales records, and iCloud customers rising from ~150m last year to over 250m this year... Faceplant, Fakebook... call it what you want, has rallied almost 100% from the lows 7 weeks ago despite what is fairly remarkable loss of active users in recent months. Yet now, after collapsing some 60% from the ipo price a few months ago, and on the hopeful promises of "monetizing mobile" by a goofy looking, freckle faced, second rate programmer gifted some gadzillions because of his theft of others ideas, Fakebook is suddenly back in favor (fervor?)? I'm not saying AAPL will rally like that, but it certainly would be fundamentally and quatitatively supported -- just ask Lazlo Biryni. It is also very possible it jumps on the 3 phones coming starting in June news bubbling from the China Times today... they tend not to make up things like that if you have studied their record.

Topic.Title: Nansen - where are you?

Message.Msg: Latest Article Apple (AAPL) came in with a mediocre report that was right in line with the analysts. People are clearly disappointed. Below is a summary of analyst’s estimates and actual results. Category Analysts Estimates Apple Results Revenue 54.74 B 54.51 B EPS 13.45 13.81 iphones 47.6 MM 47.8 MM ipads 24 MM 22.9 MM Why are people disappointed? Apple was a high growth company growing 60-80% a year and suddenly it has slowed down to 15-30% and that has everyone scared and confused. Below I lay out the last 3 years Q1 Year over Year % increase in the 4 most important areas for Apple. You can see the decrease in momentum is alarming. Category 2013 2012 2011 Revenue 18% 73% 71% EPS -0.4% 116% 75% iphones 29% 128% 86% ipads 48% 110% N.A. It’s pretty stark. Apple is decelerating fast. Is Apple still a great company with a bright future? Yes, but it will be a slower growing company with up and down quarters. It is no longer the company that originally attracted me; a company growing 100% a year selling for 13 times earnings. Can Apple accelerate its earnings growth again? Yes, it can. The iTV or China Mobile could reignite Apple. For the time being, Apple is a company with slowing growth. I have devoted 100% of my time following Apple and investing in it. I love this company and I love its products. The company no longer warrants 100% of my time. I will join my wife and begin trading 5-10 stocks like I did before I got involved with Apple. Apple will be on my list so it will get at least 10% of my time. I will not comment on Apple nearly as much because I will not study or research it like I did. I will not keep up the comment section because it obviously takes up so much of my time. I may or may not comment on what I am doing as a more active trader in the future. I said Q1 earnings would give us the truth and it did. I accept it.

Message.Title: Projected Trading Range
Message.Msg: Very infrequent poster/often-amused reader of these Yahoo boards. Coming from a pretty strong and long background of conservative investing, I think the near-term will bring a bounce off of this capitulation back up to something around $500, and then the stock will have to fall again to re-test this low around $440-450. If it breaks that, it could foreseeably get to $425 but I don't suspect it will go much lower. What I DO know, from a Keynesian perspective, is that almost every time you see dire headlines en masse from the media, that's a pretty good time to invest in a strong company.

Topic.Title: What will be the near term low for Apple - my best guess now is anywhere between

Message.Msg: At this point, I don't think anyone can say with any great certainty what they might earn in 2014. iPhone sales accounted for about 55% of revenues in the most recent quarter, I believe. Can they continue to sell phones at the current rates or greater or is the world-wide high end market saturated? Smart phones are still such a young device in terms of public use. What is the life expectancy of a phone - how often will users turn it over for a new one. If AAPl comes out with a lower priced version to compete directly with Samsung's galaxy, one that has a larger screen, who knows, if they can still hang onto the high end. But if eps did fall back to the $20-25 range, that would obviously bring the stock down considerably. But it is far too early to say one way or the other. So much can happen , good or bad, in a year's time in the life a competitive technology company.

Topic.Title: What will be the near term low for Apple - my best guess now is anywhere between

Message.Msg: Just as no one can be certain what earnings will be in 2014, I don't know that at this point Jobs being there would make any difference. Cook is a very competent operations guy, if not a visionary. He has delivered as much as any overly greedy investor could have desired in terms of profitability. But now the stock and maybe the company is at a crossroad. Innovation in their space going forward may be things that barely move the dial. This is what happens eventually in any given tech space and with any given device or family of devices. So now is it just a battle about market share in the smartphone arena, ability to retain and grow market share and if so at what cost to margins. They could try to expand into new arenas with their cash horde but this is always a very dicey game. And I don't think this is Cook's forte. to be continued

Message.Title: Time to remove the noise and dive into the facts...
Message.Msg: The facts are that the stock is down 38% in about a 4 month period which represents a significant panic overshoot as to where the company should be realistically valued. It's now selling for a lower price than lost companies who are trapped in the past and thus possess a shakey future (e.g. Microsoft). Apple is the leader in a 'future looks very bright' market -- a market that is responsible for destructing the previous dominant market segment: a.k.a. PC's. Moreover, Wall Street is viewing a lower cost phone as an Apple desperation play. They are missing the point since the idea is to lock-in as many people in the world into Apple's ecosystem as quickly as possible. Software and services is where the long-term and profitable future lies, not in the devices themselves, and creating an effective competitive moat is a means to distance ones self from the competition. Based on these facts I feel quite confident in arguing that Apple is extremely cheap and, based on conservative valuation metrics, deserves at least a PE of 12 (probably fairer at 15) after pulling out their $125 worth of cash. A super conservative 2013 earnings estimate of $40/share puts the stock at $605. I would also argue that investor sentiment is so terribly low that ANY positive news surprise at this point will result in a just-as-rapid turnaround in Apple's stock price. Next week's MacWorld may just be the initial venue for such news so we'll see. If not, the upside surprise will come soon since Apple cannot afford to have their top talent poached by the Google's and Facebook's -- and especially Samsung's, of the world. Lastly, I think it is a huge mistake, and unfair at such an early point, to put Tim Cook out to pasture so quickly. DZ

We are also cutting our EPS estimates for FY 13 (Sep.) to $44.29 from $45.25, for FY 14 to $50.66 from $53.62, and for FY 15 to $58.08 from $61.67. AAPL posted Dec-Q EPS of $13.81 vs. $13.87, below our forecast of $14.32. iPhone and iPad revenue growth was 28% and 22%, respectively, below our forecasts. But despite results we see as disappointing, we view AAPL as having strong franchises and growth opportunities. AAPL has $137 billion in cash and investments, or some $145 a share.

Topic.Title: Next market for Apple?

Message.Msg: Both a TV and a camera are coming. I believe that the TV is coming first. The camera in the iPhone will get better, but it will be a standalone camera that will be the big deal. Putting a better camera in an iPhone would drive incrementally more sales, but a revolutionary standalone camera creates a new market. There are physical limits as to what can be done with a camera module within the size constraints of an iPhone. There needs to be a larger form factor to contain the imaging chips and optics required for the amazing feats that Apple is pulling off. Expect an iOS standalone camera with wi-fi and optional cellular. Most current apps will work with the camer with little change. There will be revolutionary new ways to capture pictures and videos of utmost quality. Apps galore will be made to take advantage of the new camera features. Full iCloud integration. Expect tens of millions of people to opt to pay for larger iCloud storage plans as the easy and safety of not having to manage and/or backup your photos makes the storage cost extremely compelling. New social platform to based upon image sharing. Complete integration with the new TV to make it ultra easy to view/share/manage your images and videos.

Message.Title: Apple a software company too...400 million users
Message.Msg: With an installed base of around 400 million users, Apple is now selling 4-8 apps per month to users who "don't even think about buying 99 cent titles" Chowdhry said. That results in software revenues around $300 million per month, and future sales will grow exponentially, just as iTunes media sales have enjoyed compounded growth as its users shop the App Store via recommendations. The "new Apple," Chowdhry notes, "is not about new hardware. it's about software attach rates." Analysts tracking Apple's revenues will need to consider download volumes, the frequency of sales, and in app purchases. "Existing Apple analysts, if they don't come from a software background, will be missing a key ingredient," Chowdhry said. Apple's software revenues appear set to enjoy compounded growth of 30 percent over each of the next five years Chowdhry stated. In the US, iPhone users already spend $80 on average over the life of their phone, a significant addition to the hardware profit Apple earns on the original sale.

Topic.Title: Why should the stock value less than from the same time last year when profit actually went up & more cash in the bank?

Message.Msg: Margin. And it's all about future guidance and growth. It could also be that there was simply nowhere for the price to go from 700 except down, and as hedge funds shed their shares, the selling accelerated. Same thing happens to large companies once they're matured.. Just like microsoft peaked in the late 90's.. Look at Margins again. 2 qtrs back, 44%. Last qtr, 40.5%. This last qtr, down to 38.7%.. The markets are forward looking, aside from being criminal, and their margins are getting squeezed by competitors.. And it certainly didn't help to roll out a new iphone, 5, with a #$%$ Maps App.. Jobs would've NEVER allowed that to happen, he simply wouldn't have released the phone with an issue like that.. Followed by Cook's 'oh well' apology.. Additionally, we're in times where the Fed and our Gov't seem to think that they have to artificially stimulate growth, and what happens when you take out the stimulus..? You have bubbles and crashes, ans stocks go with them... Nothing goes up forever, never did. This is a traders market, buy and hold is a dead investment strategy..

Message.Title: China!! 3 iphones coming!!
Message.Msg: 3 iphones coming!! iphone 5? That’s so last season! Apple will release three upgraded iPhones by the end of the year — despite launching its latest model just four months ago — tech analysts and Chinese newspapers report.Two of the new models — the iPhone 5S and a first-of-its-kind low-budget iPhone — are due out by June, according to the China Times.The third device, a larger-screened iPhone 6 with a 12-pixel camera, could be available by Christmas, analysts say.The business move may be coming because Apple is feeling demand from folks who can’t afford smartphones, Wall Street tech market analyst Peter Misek told The Post. He also said the Samsung-style look of a big screen is gaining popularity. “A large percent of the population wants bigger screens — so there’s a demand for that and it’s hurting them,” Misek said.Misek — who correctly predicted past iPhone features— said he is “confident” that the iPhone 5s will have an 8-megapixel camera and will hit shops by June. He also said the company’s “affordable” $250 iPhone will be heavier and made of polycarbonate material. The iPhone 6 will likely feature a 4.8 inch screen, he said.The move is unusual for Apple, which has in the past released only one iPhone per year.Natalie Harrison, a spokeswoman for Apple, refused to offer details about any in-the-works products.

If you followed the AH tape there was a direct correlation to when apple guided revenue and talked about giving a range that was more in line with given parameters of estimates. The market took that to mean apple will no longer be sandbagging so the revenue guidance was more in line with the reality and thus indicted they would be missing next qtr. Growth investors ran for the hills and went to greener pastures which proved to be the right move, ie look at Rimm, Netflix and even Google. Apple is in Limbo as the market is going to stay away until they give a clear sign that growth is coming back. If that is not the case Apple must go to plan B and attract value investors with buybacks and dividend increases. Personally I think they can attract value investors now and growth investors later in the year when new products arrive. Apple may not care to do that and so we suffer in the short term and my calls expire worthless.

Topic.Title: earnings was a reasonable increase over their last year's blow out quarter.

Message.Msg: This year's Christmas quarter was amazing, all things considered. Apple sold about 4 million iPhones per week. Add an extra week, like they had last year, and you end up with 52 million iPhones sold. Add in the missed 1-1.5 billion from the lack of the iMac supply and add in another billion or so from the iPad mini supply constraints. Had everything aligned, (extra week like last year and supply met) you'd be looking at about a $15-$16 quarter. Using this knowledge, you know that, in the future, if Apple is able to iron out the supply chain, and add a few carriers, you can anticipate a $15+ quarter next Christmas. Add in a China Mobile deal and a possible iTV, and that number probably closes in on $20.

Message.Title: WSJ said AAPL will go down furthu. Read why. Very funny story.
Message.Msg: If you have this weekend's WSJ, check page B1 for the whole story . I can recap the story here. Basically many WS firms sold "Structured Bond linking to AAPL stock" to super conservative bond buyers. The rules are 1. The bond is actually one year note. You paid $700 upfront. In the end of one year, you get your principal $700 back if AAPL stays above $700 at that time. 2. If AAPL drops below $700, you get one share of AAPL instead, no matter what the AAPL share price is. 3. This bond pays 10% annual interest rate by month. The fee is 2% so the effective interest rate is 8%. The pitch to the public is that AAPL is the safest stock. It will stay above $700 so it is almost risk free bond paying high interest. By comparison, one year note (normal one) only pays 1% annual interest. It seems to be too good to be true to get 10% interest so bond buyers piled in to thank these Wall Street firms to let them buy these special structured bonds. According to WSJ, about $800 millions of such instrument were sold when AAPL was peaked at $700 to $705 in September. Now these bond holders accidentally bought AAPL shares at $700 LAST WEEK. LOL. WSJ said these people will be constantly AAPL sellers because of their conservative nature. And there is no way AAPL can get back to $700 in September 2013. These people have been put shares of AAPL last week when AAPL dropped 20%.

Topic.Title: AAPL winning over Android Tablet with Mini IPad, surely AAPL will win over smart phone war with cheaper IPhone...

Message.Msg: It's simple, really. It will be a LOT easier for Apple to go from the high end users to the lower end users than it will be for Android/Windows/Samsung to go from the lower end users to the higher end users. Apple has the high end users "locked in" to their ecosystem. In most cases, people have hundreds, if not thousands, of dollars locked into iTunes, Apps, iPods, etc. It would take an absolutely astounding technology for them to leave all of this behind and go start over with no apps, music, etc. Now you might think that a matching music service from Amazon is a threat, but that's not necessarily the case. People have an emotional attachment to money spent, and they tend to stay where their money is invested and familiarity lies. The lower end users? They have virtually nothing invested, and the temptation to hold something they were never able to afford (an iPhone at a lower price) will likely see many defectors. In short, Apple has a far easier road to hoe than Windows/Samsung/Android. You might wonder why I didn't mention RIM. They're simply not worth mentioning. They'll cease to exist in about 36 months.

Message.Title: Apple Sauce...food for thought
Message.Msg: Q2 of last year was really strong with a quarterly EPS of 12ish, based on AAPLs guidance they will earn about $8.70-9.20/sh. You should always invest in the future not the past. So, why the shrinking margins? Here's some food for thought. Last quarter AAPL gave back $4.5 billion in stock repurchases and dividends, with just shy of one billion shares, they gave back $4.5 dollars a share. A year ago that number was zero. With the CFO stating that AAPL will give back $45 billion over the next year, $7.5 billion of repurchases which the company still has authorization to use right now, and $2.5 billion in dividends payable for Q1. These are the things that everyone was screaming about, spend money, I think they should have just done a repurchase, but AAPL is doing what everyone was asking them to do which in doing so shrinks margins. They have increased their inventory by double from last year to about $1.5 billion. Bears will say that is proof that their product isn't in demand. Based on the numbers AAPL released the only product lines shrinking in sales were IMacs, a recent article stated that there is a 2-3 week waiting period for IMacs due to supply constraints. So, that suggests that the one product not included in the increase of inventory is the one that isn't selling very well. There are also more products being produced at once, suggesting that the increase in inventory is due to more production, not less demand. They also increased their quarterly R&D expense by about 33% to over a billion dollars. Everyone should be happy with this, because it spells innovation. I am not suggesting that anyone jump right into this stock, but I am suggesting if you have a basis above $600 it may be hard to get your money back.
